title: 104_hr2242
content: SECTION 1. PROHIBITION. The Secretary cannot issue a lease, permit, or license for oil or gas exploration on submerged lands within 100 miles of the Outer Continental Shelf. No exploration or extraction is allowed after lease cancellation, but ongoing activities are permitted under existing leases. The Act prohibits oil and gas exploration on submerged lands within 100 miles of the Outer Continental Shelf for Florida, Georgia, and South Carolina, and within 175 miles for other areas. The Act prohibits oil and gas exploration on submerged lands within 175 miles of the coast of North Carolina, 100 miles of the coast of Virginia, 50 miles of the coast of Maryland, and 100 miles of the coast of Delaware. The Act extends the moratorium on oil and gas leasing activities within 125 miles of the coast of New Jersey and New York. The Act extends the moratorium on oil and gas leasing activities within 125 miles of the coast of Connecticut, Rhode Island, and within 50 miles of the coast of Massachusetts. The Act extends the moratorium on oil and gas leasing activities within specific blocks surrounding Georges Bank, identified by the Department of the Interior. The Act extends the moratorium on oil and gas leasing activities within specific blocks surrounding Georges Bank, identified by the Department of the Interior, including submerged lands within 100 miles of the Outer Continental Shelf. The Act extends the moratorium on oil and gas leasing activities within specific blocks surrounding Georges Bank, including submerged lands within 100 miles of the Outer Continental Shelf in various states like New Hampshire, Maine, California, and Oregon. The Act extends the moratorium on oil and gas leasing activities in specific areas near Georges Bank, including submerged lands within 100 miles of the Outer Continental Shelf in Washington and Alaska. It excludes portions of the Central or Western Gulf of Mexico planning areas. The Secretary of the Interior is authorized to cancel any lease or permit in effect. The Secretary of the Interior can cancel leases or permits in specified areas, entitling the lessee to compensation. The areas include lands south of 26 degrees north latitude and east of 86 degrees west longitude, as well as the North Aleutian Basin planning area. The Secretary must report to Congress by May 1, 1996, on compensation options for leaseholders in specific blocks. The protraction diagram NI 18-2 of the Universal Transverse Mercator Grid System includes compensation procedures for Outer Continental Shelf leases, with options for credits in lieu of appropriations.
